ultimately they kind of they're just helping the party tell their story and in project management and software
development this is what i would like a project manager to be someone who helps steer
the direction helps sort of guide the team along the right path
but doesn't force them down any particular route doesn't force them to do what they deem is necessary
you don't tell people what to do you hire them because they're smart and they're intelligent and they've got skills that you need and you value and you let them work

part of being a dungeon master is sort of improvising and being able to think on the fly being a project manager is being able to

what the team as a whole including yourself has decided

to have a balance if everyone in the team is just agreeing with that one person that's in charge

without just the whole thing devolving into chaos because everyone thinks they've got the best idea

character of alignment of background of skill of expertise a cleric a fighter a
warrior a wizard a rogue a hunter a druid all of these people bring different skills to the party
and the same with software development these mixed skill teams allow you to be able to cover a lot more areas
you're not always trying to kill dragons in the dungeon you're not always revolutionizing the world with new features you're sneaking
through alleys in a city or you're hunting down a bug that no one's been able to solve for the past two years you're disarming traps as you track a
bandit through a forest or you're fending off distractions on meetings and emailing email invites and that guy steve who
keeps sending you cat gifts which they're really cute but they don't help with your work that you're doing
you're negotiating that lower price of the magic wand you want to buy or you're negotiating with teams outside of you who are
trying to demand things and ask for more requirements and put pressure on you to deliver features that they want when you've got
your own backlog and priorities a balanced party leads to more
possibilities you don't always have to take the same approach to everything because you've got different ways of thinking you might have someone who's good with
communications you still have someone who's good with the back end and the algorithm side of things you've got someone who's got a really

the way in which the team forms together your problem solvers as a developer you

different minds different interests different people all lend themselves to more creative ways

for the people outside the team they need to trust the team they need to don't try and control them

you set out on your journey and after a short while everything is going well along the way
you've met a few folks along the path that you're on and you've capped out and kept monitor that anything might seek to ambush you in the night
each time a team is formed i've found myself that they do go through some form of tuckman stages of group development
now this is not a scientifically sort of proven thing there's been studies that tried to verify it and they
can't and some studies that have tried to disprove it and they seem to be able to do that anecdotally i find that the teams that
i've been in and the teams that i've been a part of and leader of have all gone through this in some form or another
where the team starts forming and they're an independently behaving team
of people they're motivated but they're uninformed of issues and the objectives of the team
they're sort of more for themselves and then they reach the storming phase where they're all loudly voiced opinions
there's disputes there's people trying to sort of form the dominant position in the group and get their opinion in because it matters
more than someone else's there's the norming stage where they actually they start realizing that none of that matters and
they're a team of people and it's not an individual thing and they start moving towards harmonious working practices and
agreements on the rules and how things might might work within the team and then they hit the performing stage where they're
motivated they're knowledgeable they're competent they're autonomous and they all have aligned goals and values
you wake up one morning the sun already bright in the sky and you hear a voice excitedly say hey folks mind if i join you you see an
elven figure green robe and flowers in their hair it would appear you've come across a druid who sought to join you on your quest
now it's going to happen both in dungeons and dragons and in real life you're going to have someone new join your team or even someone leave your
team it's unfortunate but that's the world now it'll upset your team balance
everyone who's found their role and their position within the team and their sort of individual skill set to sort of work towards a group dynamic
now realizes there's another person there and it's gonna shift that balance when you have someone
join your team or someone leave your team you don't have a changed team you have a new team teams are immutable
so this druid joins us and they bring a new set of skills with them they bring a set of skills in testing that we didn't have
before i know everyone kind of goes well i was doing a little bit of that before but now i don't have to necessarily worry about it as much or maybe they
worry about it more or they improve their skills in that area because they've got someone to mentor and teach them
but once this person joins the team we go through this stage again they go back through the forming stage they go back through the
storming stage maybe less so they go back to the norming stage before they hit the performing stage again once
everyone refines their balance within this new team
you've made great progress on your journey you're nearing the castle and as you see the castle in the

you end up talking for hours upon hours upon hours and then only at the end of it do you realize that half the people

is to backtrack but if you check in at regular intervals whilst you're
having these conversations then you don't have to backtrack as far
and people don't spend as long and not as much time is wasted every half an hour or so just check in to make sure that the things that have

anything in because in reality they've switched off they're thinking about what they're going to be doing in their dungeons and dragons game later on that night because
the discussion they're having is not engaging for them make sure that people are taking in the information that you're
going through in these sessions and i would also say keeping the session shorter rather than longer is going to be helpful
i've seen this happen especially with newer members of a team um people that are just sort of willing to
please and they kind of nod along like they know what's going on because they want to give a good impression to a team and
i've seen it happen with juniors and seniors and apprentices at and mid-levels and architects everyone at some point will switch off in a

knowledge silos like that are a barrier to effective team performance if you have knowledge that could be useful to the team you should share it
you should not keep it to yourself thinking that you're maintaining job security by that that will only lead to toxicity within
the team and your reliance being more and more relied upon which is actually not good for you
now wizards are often the smartest smart ass know-it-alls with a superior superiority complex both in dungeons and
dragons and code wizards they want to hoard the knowledge it's theirs it doesn't belong to anyone else
but that information works best when it's shared with everyone
sometimes you might need that wizard to do something that no one else can do sometimes you need them to cast fireball

in d if you push on constantly you suffer exhaustion you can no longer perform the duties
that you've set out to do as well because you're just too tired in real life we have the same thing
and the most important and productive thing you can do in software development is stop go home and do something else for a while get a good night's sleep

immediately come to you and you think of course it's that that time that rest that sleep that ability
to give your brain something else to focus on is crucial to problem solving

it's not over when that piece of software is deployed to production you can't just push it to the server and then ignore it and go you know what i'm

that they shouldn't have gone down as they walk into the distance they surely won't make those mistakes next

when you're you've got the the thing deployed to production and the monitoring and the logging is there and

for us use past experience to help you with the unknowns in your software journey
